Hi joebrummer:
 
 
How can a museum about creationism show "Fossil" collections? Aren;t those more about supporting evolution? I am very puzzled!

 
 Same evidence, different interpretations based on different starting faiths.
 
 We will use the Lucy type skeleton and the next supposed evolutionary progression Homo Hablis (for short hand, HH). CAT scans of the inner ear of HH showed that the semi-circular cannals, which determine balance and locomotion, are more like those of baboons than those of humans. This is not what one would expect if the evolutionary story about human origins is true, HH should be more bipedal than the Lucy type skeleton from which it supposedly evolved from, but it is not. In fact, most scientists now think that HH is not one creature, but instead is several types of creatures that do not belong together, at least three or more different animals, hence making it an invalid category. Further more, it cannot be our ancestor as no such animal ever existed.
 
 Hence, the evidence is interpreted more sensibly and reasonable through a creationary model. This is just an example of what they may do with some fossils, IMVHO.

To pandion:
 
 
Any similarity to the Natural History Museum in London is imaginary. None of the displays in London are based on mythology.

 
 You have to think in context to what this is. The world before Adam's Fall and after is very important to the Christian doctrine as it sets many rules (e.g. marriage) and answers many questions (e.g. why death and suffering). It tells us that we all fall short of God's glory and need His Son to take away our sins. They are just showing what it may have been like.
 
 Creation is based on the belief that the Bible is God's Word and as a result, that it is truth. This is a reasonable and rational assumption. Atheistic evolutionism is based on the belief that there is no God and as such, the Bible is wrong. Therefore, everything must be explained by natural processes. If you continue to ignore this fundamental point, than it is pointless talking to you. 
 
 They will be displaying the same scientific evidence and then be pointing out aspects of that evidence that points to creation being true as opposed to evolutionism, see example above in my previous post for a good example of this. What is the Natural History Museum in London? It is a place where they discuss our origins from an evolutionary point of view. What will the Creation Museum be? It is a place where they will discuss our origins from a creationary point of view. They are both museums for discussing what may have happened in the past based on two different underlying assumptions. No, there is no similarities, is there? Ignorance. The only difference between them is the underlying assumptions, or belief systems. 
 
 Creation - based on a literal read of the Bible.
 Atheistic evolution - based on the religous belief of atheism.
 
 Because creation is based on the Bible, it will obviously talk about the Garden of Eden, the Fall, the Flood, the seperation of the people and confusion of their languages at Babel and may be the Good News of Jesus Christ - who knows?
 
 The only reason why the museum at London does not talk about the Flood, etc., is because of it's atheistic interpretation of the evidence and not acknowledging the Bible as the Written Word of God.

Hi sinjin:
 
 
No, the reason is that there is no objective evidence that any of these things actually existed or happened.

 
 Thus you show your ignorance of the evidence and what I have been saying for a long time. I would not usually use capitals, but just for you to see the main ideas, I will use them for you. BOTH creationists AND evolutionists have the SAME scientific evidence. The only reason why they come to different conclusions about it's [the evidence's] origin is because the have different INTERPRETATIONS about the evidence that is BASED on their STARTING FAITHS of UNDERLYING BELIEFS, i.e. atheism or Christianity. This is not a hard concept to understand! 
 
 To an atheist, the evolutionary view is true because it matches with his/her starting assumptions or underlying beliefs. A belief in God and the subsquent creation model is considered by these people to be lies and false as it goes against his/her underlying beliefs (i.e. there is no God). The opposite is for creationists. They consider a belief in evolution to be false as it goes against their underlying beliefs (i.e. the truth of the Bible). All of their science goes from this underlying belief.
 
 You have deomonstrated this idea clearly in your post. You claim that there is no evidence or no objective evidence for a global flood, this is from your atheistic evolutionary point-of-view (easier said than done). If you are going to make such claims, you should take off your evolutionary world view glasses and put on the creationary world view glasses. When you look at the same evidence through different world views, you will be surprised at the conclusion you will come up with. Many creation scientists (who have changed from evolution to creation) say that when they were evolutionists they saw no evidence for creation. But when they became Christians and creationists, they saw plently evidence for creation - which really emphasises the point that what conclusion we will arrive at after looking at the evidence depends on what world view you have (i.e. your starting assumptions/faiths). 
 
 What an evolutionist describes as taking long periods of time to produce, such as the Grand Canyon, a creationist would state that the Grand Canyon only took a short time to be produced by using DIFFERENT ASSUMPTIONS (i.e. the Flood) to those ASSUMPTIONS used by the evolutionist (i.e. slow and steady - the present is the key to the past). They are both equally valid as science cannot state which one is right, because science cannot deal with the past. BOTH creationists and evolutionists look at the Grand Canyon and ask themselves, "What can we see from this evidence that supports our theory?"
 
 These links provide substantial evidence for Noah's Flood:
 * Flood Q&A 
 * Geology Q&A 
 
 
Most atheists are former believers whose faith did not survive rational thought.

The main reason why these "former believer's" faith did not survive is not from the belief being unrational, but most likely from many unanswered questions, such as "Why is there death and suffering in the world?" (like John Kerry is 'Catholic' but believes in 'abortion' which his own church condemns (rightly))

 Why do you insist on misrepresenting the views of others? John Kerry has expressed his personal moral opposition to abortion on several occasions. What John Kerry has said is that he is unwilling to impose his morality on others by force of law. Thus he upholds the traditions of his country, where religious freedom (to worship or not) is one of the foundations. As Thomas Jefferson, the third President, put it, there is a "wall of separation" between church and state. Given the familiarity of the founding fathers with the religious wars of Europe, and given the eclectic nature of the population of the United States of the revolutionary period, the founding fathers thought it best to exclude religion from government and to exclude government from religion.
 
 Kerry was raised an American and educated as an American, including his legal training that included as study of constitutional law. Therefore he can personally and morally oppose abortion and at the same time recognize the legal right of a woman to decide her own fate - within limits.
 
 To claim that Kerry "believes" in abortion is either an ignorant statement or a malicious lie. How many times does he have to make statements declaring his opposition to abortion before the brain dead get the picture?
 
 By the way, I am strongly opposed to abortion for almost every reason (there are some exceptions about which I am ambivelant). However, abortions in this country are legal within some limits, so as a matter of respect for the law of my country, I refrain from pushing pregnant women who are trying to enter abortion clinics to the ground. I refrain from shooting clinic staff as they come to work in the morning. These things just don't seem to me to be in the spirit of my country even if they are admired by most christians.
 
 All in all, wouldn't it be better if you reported the truth rather than misrepresent what others have said? It seems that you are willing to slander and misrepresent those who disagree with you. Or maybe you just aren't willing to learn the facts before you speak.

 I can only comment on Hindu creation because that is the only one im studying currently.
 
 There are two aspects to creation. First is the creation of the physical universe, the second is the creation of life.
 
 The physical universe came into being because a higher being created it. The creation was the result of this higher being experimenting with its own life, much as a newborn child does. The creation of this higher being is sketchy, but it involves the higher being first realizing its own existance (i have more to research). The first things it created were other higher beings(replication). After creating the beings, it then comtemplated upon its own death, and realized that its death would not result in the destruction of its creations. So, finally, after a while, it died.
 
 One of the higher beings it created was called Bhraman(?). This God then "exploded" its soul (big bang, anyone? except developed several thousand years ago) and created the known universe. In addition to the known universe, this explosion also created Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva.
 
 Brahma installs life (read: soul) into a physical body. Vishnu looks after the body through its journey in life, and Shiva recycles the soul after the body is unable to sustain itself (reincarnation).
 
 Also, Hindu philosophy accepts evolution as the way the physical embodiments of life came into existence. God merely created the universe, he did not create every single thing inside of it.
 
 So thats creation in a nutshell.
 
 Trying to explain this has now made me want to re-learn the process. I think ill do that now.
 
 This has also made me curious as to what Islamic creation says. I think ill look that up too, in addition to scientology.
 
 Oh, and check out my signature. The quote reflects the thinking of Hindu philosophers. The quote is from the Rig Veda, which is one of the most religious texts in Hinduism.

 I guess i do have a limited imagination, thats why i never have been to good at telling a good fairy tale..

 
 Every species alive today represents an unbroken chain leading back to the very first lifeforms. This is common sense. Otherwise they would be extinct.
 My point was that "evidence" for common ancestry is easily seen in something as simple as "two eyes". It was not your imagination I was suggesting might be judged as limited but God's.

Appearently there are many other indigenous groups from around the whole world that tell of a catastrophic flood!  I thought Noah and his happy family were the only ones who survived.
 
 Genesis 7:21-23: 
 
 7:21 And all flesh died that moved upon the earth, both of fowl, and of cattle, and of beast, and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth, and every man: 
 7:22 All in whose nostrils was the breath of life, of all that was in the dry land, died. 
 7:23 And every living substance was destroyed which was upon the face of the ground, both man, and cattle, and the creeping things, and the fowl of the heaven; and they were destroyed from the earth: and Noah only remained alive, and they that were with him in the ark 
 
 Maybe a translational error?

Every species alive today represents an unbroken chain leading back to the very first lifeforms. This is common sense. Otherwise they would be extinct.

Which cannot be done because the very reason we have mysteries is because they dont fit with the evolution world view

 And the Natural History Museum in London looks like a church. How appropriate.
OccamsRazor

And the Natural History Museum in London looks like a church. How appropriate.

 
 Actually, being there a few weeks ago I cannot fully agree with your aesthetic appraisal of the building. I assume you are refering to the main entrance area which does bear resemblance to the front sections of Cathedrals, two of which it always puts me in mind of are Notre Dame and York Minster.
 
 When the front facia of the building is viewed in its entireity it is not entirely unlike one of the wings of the Louvre, with a tower at the end of the long straight building.
 
 Alfred Waterhouse who designed the Natural History Museum was interested in the Gothic style, and this is the strong influence that carries though in the buildings appearance. It was a grand Victorian design as well, and it also bears this influence quite clearly.
montalban

Actually, being there a few weeks ago I cannot fully agree with your aesthetic appraisal of the building. I assume you are refering to the main entrance area which does bear resemblance to the front sections of Cathedrals, two of which it always puts me in mind of are Notre Dame and York Minster.
 
 When the front facia of the building is viewed in its entireity it is not entirely unlike one of the wings of the Louvre, with a tower at the end of the long straight building.
 
 Alfred Waterhouse who designed the Natural History Museum was interested in the Gothic style, and this is the strong influence that carries though in the buildings appearance. It was a grand Victorian design as well, and it also bears this influence quite clearly.

 
 When I was in London I preferred the National Portrait Gallery over all others, but I prefer history to naturalism and pre-history (though I did Pre-history at university).
